One would think that all Creative-types at Apple loved Steve Jobs because he endorses art, design, innovationâ€¦ but â€œcreative differencesâ€ are some of the worst and most opinionated contentions alongside forward development.

Especially when developing privately, in secret, nobody can say, â€œ15% of the representative potential market voted in favor of rectangles, whereas , 45% like circles, 10% like squares, and 30% like rounded squares.â€

Instead, Steve says, â€œI like the rounded squares, and thatâ€™s that. It gets frustrating to have design politics, and you just have to know thatâ€™s the way it is.

In less creative and more scientific endeavors, something that is 15% more efficient and 15% lower in costs wins decisively.

This is so true to reality: Steve Jobs wanted to kill the â€œiPhoneâ€ project, and did, at one time cease development. But, he also later supported it.

The same person who gets credit for green-lighting a project that succeeds also stopped (red-lighted) it multiple times. Thatâ€™s the schizophrenic nature of people credited for things: they disappointed people, created burnout, etc., altogether known as the â€œhuman costâ€ of new technology.

Apple probably claimed to invent the mouse (Doug Englebart), desktop metaphor and Ethernet (Xerox Parc). I wish Steve Jobs would say that Apple improved Multi-Touch for introduction into the iPhone, rather than inventing it, but thatâ€™s simply not Steve Jobsâ€™ style. Never was.

A couple of things about this: 1) It was never called iOS to start off with. It was always iPhone OS. The name was only changed with the introduction of iOS 4 - three years after the introduction of the iPhone. 2) Apple didn't start off designing the iPhone first. Once the phone was done, they then started work on the tablet. Aside from that, great documentary.

Steve Jobs didnâ€™t envision the iPhone. The original concept of the iPhone came from an Apple employee walking down Garnett Ave in San Diego asking out loud. â€œI work for Apple, does anyone have an idea for a phone?â€ The idea was crowdsourced by an Apple employee from a bouncer who had a customer complain about mobile web and asking â€œwhy donâ€™t they have the entire internet on cellphones?â€ The bouncer told the Apple employee that he had an idea for a phone, â€œhow about a phone with the entire internet on it?â€ The Apple employee responded â€œhave you seen the screen on cell phones? You never be able to see the internetâ€ he was talking about 2002 phones. The bouncer responded â€œ Why donâ€™t you just make the entire front of the phone the screen?â€ Recalling custom card makers he saw in Kmart as a kid. If from the 1980â€™s to now 2002 we come this far with our technology wouldnâ€™t it be possible to make smaller version of touch screen for the phone. The whole internet on the phone came from an unknown customer complaining about mobile web, the front of the phone being the screen, pinch zoom, a gyro inside that turns the screen came from the bouncer, the iPod inside, location and maps came from the Apple employee. The original idea had a task bar in the UI, admittedly there UI Apple came up with was much better, but the iPhone and iPad ideas didnâ€™t come from anyone at Apple. The iPad was a version of the PDA(personal digital assistant) from the Doom pc game thought up by the bouncer. Apple was supposed to put money into education and propose a thinking class as school curriculum as compensation to the bouncer. That never happened.  This is a true story, I was there in 2002 on Garnett in front of Sinbad Cafe where it happened., Sinbad has bouncers?

In hindsight itâ€™s crazy to think about the fact that for a device that was dismissed at first, and almost didnâ€™t happen, has become apples main thing as a source of revenue. iPhones account for half of apples annual revenue. If iPhones fell off it could very realistically end apple with how dependent it is on its sales.

One of the wild things about the original iPhone for me, in hindsight, is how the first model ran on Edge networks. I find that interesting because Edge as a network is so slow when it comes to the internet that I canâ€™t imagine that the phones internet capabilities on the original model were all that great. They probably seemed great for the time when considering where technology was at the time, but Iâ€™ll always wonder just how useful any of the web features were on that original model. I do remember that as a young kid when the first model came out that I was just amazed for something like it to exist. I was 13 when it was announced so it was just mind blowing. But I didnâ€™t end up using an iPhone until I bought an iPhone 4 from somebody in 2011 when they had just bought a 4s. For a lot of years Iâ€™ve usually switched between iPhone and android. Itâ€™s kinda ironic in a way that for a phone that was so revolutionary at the start that in later years it really has never made more jumps like that. Itâ€™s still a great phone, which I use currently, but it is kinda ironic how the company that was so far ahead at the beginning has now generally been a few steps behind about technology and features released in their new devices each year., Or other things like true GPS navigation on the device. Wow, what a huge miss on your part. The smart phone and its interface was devised by Marc Porat (starting in 1989) and the team with General Magic, an offshoot of Apple, back in the early 1990's. They had essentially laid out the design and approach of the device. Since the wireless infrastructure at the time was so small, launching that product would have been difficult. The company dissolved, Apple instead invested in the Newton, and the iPhone was a resurrection of that device when wireless systems could support it.

The iPhone wasn't anything substantially different than the visions of Porat and the General Magic team.

I hate the smart phone -- it has so distracted people from the real world. I have witnessed more traffic fatalities due to phone distraction, unnecessarily long delays at traffic lights because people were so busy texting, etc. My great uncle, 117 years old and the sharpest, most active person ever met, was run over by a guy jumping a curb as he was on his daily 5 mile walk because the guy was too busy responding to a text. My nieces text each other while walking side-by-side, constantly think they hear phantom chirps from silent phones, and turn into nervous wrecks if I get a message and do not check it IMMEDIATELY ("I'll read it after we get home."). These distractions retard our ability to concentrate and create and think for ourselves. It is creating a world of sheep who follow instructions because that is the fastest way to get back to their devices. What happened to our ability to remember the things we think and memorize details of things we see? And what is this obsession with getting online phone-fame? Trust me -- glorious anonymity will make you far happier than anyone can dare imagine.
